discussion.content:
The best first step to remedy this issue would be D. Close all running applications.
When a phone application is not functioning properly, it could be due to the device’s resources being overutilized by other applications. Closing all running applications can free up system resources and may resolve the issue. If this doesn’t work, then the technician can proceed with the other options like checking the network connection, reinstalling the application, or as a last resort, performing a hard reset on the phone. Remember, it’s always best to start with the least disruptive solution first.

There's no reason why D should be the answer. Both Apple and experts had came out and said numerous times that closing running applications do not do anything good for the device, only increases processing/ram usage.
any comments on this? why not A.

questions.question_text: A user reports that a cell phone application is loading slowly and not functioning properly. Which of the following should a technician do FIRST to remedy this issue?
Which of the following types of scripts would be seen on the user end of a web page?

discussion.content: Professor messer has VBS is for general purpose scripting in windows including Back-end web server scripting. He has JS as scripting inside of your browser. I would go with javascript

.vbs (vbscript, visual basic) is defunct in web design. Owned by Microsoft, it was supposed to be a competitor to JavaScript. Firstly, it is only supported in Internet Explorer. Secondly, IE has vbscript disabled by default.
.js (JavaScript) is supported by all browsers and is widely and commonly used in Web design. HTML5 incorporates js as part of the standard.
The answer is absolutely .js

I can confirm that .js is indeed the correct answer. I selected that on this exact question on my exam, and my score report didn't indicate I misanswered any of the scripting-related questions; otherwise, it would have included the "4.8 – Identify the basics of scripting" objective.

days you can find it in command-line programs,
extensions for many desktop applications, and much
more.

When you right click on any web page, it brings "view page source" option. You click it and search "vbs". It is not gonna bring any result even if you are at user end. But, if you search "js", it will bring many results. So, it means "js" is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: B
I believe the answer should be B, .js.
From Comptia:
JavaScript is a scripting language that is designed to create interactive web-based content and web apps. 
VBScript is often used by network administrators to perform repetitive administrative tasks.

Key Differences Between JavaScript and VBScript
JavaScript is not a true object-oriented scripting language as it doesn’t support inheritance concept, subroutines. Still, it supports the usage of an object, the definition of classes for subsequent object creation. In contrast, VBScript is also not a true object-oriented scripting language as it doesn’t support inheritance, object usage, and classes usage but supports reusable functions and subroutines.
JavaScript is a default scripting language for most of browsers, whereas VBScript is not a default scripting language, and we need to mention it as a scripting language.
JavaScript is a case-sensitive scripting language, whereas VBScript is not a case-sensitive scripting language.
JavaScript syntax is similar to the C programming language, whereas VBScript syntax is similar to Visual Basic as it is a subpart of it, and it follows the syntax of the visual basic.
JavaScript is used as a client-side scripting language, whereas VBScript can be used as both server-side and client-side scripting language.

discussion.content:
The key word is scripting language. Both Visual Basic script and JavaScript are scripting languages. So, both .js and .vbs are correct answers.
Unfortunately, both can appear as part of web pages and applications. While we are more likely to observe JavaScript in the wild, VBScript is also used on web pages, usually to execute tasks in a more active manner. It's hard to say which of these two is the "most correct" answer.

comments.content: Just to point out .bat is for batch scripts and .sh is for shell scripts so all are scripting extensions. However .js and .vbs are the two that are designed for running in web pages. As others have pointed out vbs never really made it in the web world, and isn't supported by many modern browsers, so the "most correct" answer here would be .js
VB running only on service side. JavaScript running in browser on client side. Correct answer is .js

Selected Answer: B

Selected Answer: B
Group Policy is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
All security should be done using security groups for a few reasons. The first reason is a simple one: you want to administer groups of users and not individual users. It is easier
to apply permissions to a group of users than individual users. As the resource needs to be shared by more people, you never have to revisit the resource to apply the new permissions if a group is used. All you need to do is add the new users to the group and they will have access.
Group policy is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: B
Group Policy for sure, who the fxxk is Security Groups

Selected Answer: B
You can use organizational units (OUs) that organize users and devices logically into a folder-like hierarchy, and then exercise deity-like (Microsoft prefers the term granular) control to apply a different group policy to the network clients in each unit. 
- Mike Meyers e-book

Answer Is (B) Group Policy According To My Understanding.

"Group Policy is a hierarchical infrastructure that allows a network administrator in charge of Microsoft's Active Directory to implement specific configurations for users and computers. Group Policy is primarily a security tool, and can be used to apply security settings to users and computers."

https://searchwindowsserver.techtarget.com/definition/Group-Policy

Security groups are a group of objects in Active Directory, be it computer objects or users or other security groups. They don't do anything but aggregate objects into a single object, as you would expect anything named "Group" to do.

You can then use a Security Group to set file permissions for example, which saves you having to define every single user individually everywhere you want them to have access, but there's a lot of other uses for Security Groups.

Group Policies on the other hand are common settings you want to apply to machines in your environment based upon different factors, for example you might want to apply printer settings for all users in an office.

You can also combine a Group Policy with a Security Group by defining for example that users belonging to Security_Group_X should have Group_Policy Printer_Settings_Office_X applied to them.

Before you go implementing a lot of either, it's advantages to come up with a naming scheme for them. Some environments like to name all their group policy objects starting with GPO_ and all their Security Groups with ACL_, others uses # at the start of Security Group names. It doesn't really matter what you use, as long as there's some sort of system.

Correct me if i'm wrong but i think the key is in the wording. "can be applied directly to an organizational unit " - you don't "apply" a security group to anything, you add users or computers to it then add or remove permissions for that group. You "apply" a group policy object to to an organizational unit, which can contain users, computers or both depending on how it's been structured.
So the correct answer has to be group policy

Security: Security groups allow you to manage user and computer access to shared resources. You can also control who receives group policy settings. ... You can't use distribution groups to assign permissions on any objects, and you can't use them to filter group policy settings.

B — Group Policy — GPO’s (Group Policy Objects) containing security rules can be applied to OU’s (Organizational Units) containing User and Computer objects (accounts).
Not C — Within Active Directory you can only use ‘security group’ membership to allow or disallow members of a group from applying a GPO (dictating whether they must conform or not conform to the rules defined in the policy) – does not provide security directly to the user and machine.
Security Groups is not even an A+ objective, Group Policy is.

Organizational Unit - Group policies assigned to the Active Directory organizational unit (OU) in which the computer or user are placed. (OUs are logical units that help organizing and managing a group of users, computers or other Active Directory objects.) If multiple policies are linked to an OU, they are processed in the order set by the administrator. Examples of this are, Password length/complexity. Password History ect...

Confusing. Group policy grants permissions to Security Group privileges via Active Directory to users/machines. So there is an argument for both. However, I think it is actually the Security Groups which actually provide that security.

from what i learned security groups are for NTFS permissions 
and Organizational units are for group policy
Based on my experience, GP is the correct answer here.
Can't find security group on exam objective. so I would go for Group Policy which is the right answer.
Knee-jerk answer is Group Policy but the correct one really is Security Groups [C].

comments.content: Security Groups are objects in AD and in OU. Group Policy applied policy to OU.
